Executive Summary 



The Hormel Foods facility located in Algona, Iowa is a pork processing facility.  The primary purpose of this facility is to process raw pork into food products for distribution to retailers.  We have a strong commitment to operate our facility in a safe and responsible manner. 



The ammonia is contained in a closed loop system; it is designed to remain inside the piping and vessels in our facility. Ammonia as contained in equipment in the facility is compressed, condensed and evaporated to remove heat from within the facility to maintain safe storage areas and remove heat from the products being handled.  We believe that ammonia provides the safest and most efficient cooling choice for our operation. 



Ammonia is classified by EPA as a toxic chemical and it is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling it to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the health threat to our own workers, and reduce the threat to nearby members of the community.  It is our policy to adhere to all Federal and State rules and regulations.  Safety depends upon the manner in which we handle ammonia, safety devices inherent in the design of this facility, safe handling procedures that we use and the training of our personnel.



A. Accident Release Prevention and Emergency Policies 



An accidental release prevention program has been in place since 1994 under the PSM standard. The facility was designed and constructed in accordance with the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) guidelines, and is in compliance with State codes.  This food processing facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable State codes and regulations.



We take many precautions to prevent or minimize accidental releases of ammonia from the refrigeration system. These precautions include safety controls (alarms and automatic shutdown devices) which are designed to identify and prevent potentially unsafe conditi

ons like pressure increases that could cause a system failure. We also have a preventive maintenance program designed to maintain the on-going integrity of the systems, a training program designed to ensure that the systems are operated by qualified personnel and emergency response procedures that enable trained personnel to respond quickly to system upsets. 



The Manager of Plant Engineering is responsible for the management of these ammonia safety programs. 



B. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled 



Ammonia is the only substance covered by the Accidental Release Prevention Regulations handled at this facility. 



C. Description of the Accidental Release Prevention Program 



The facility has an accident release prevention program that complies with Occupational Safety and Health Act's Process Safety Management Standard and EPA's Risk Management Program Rule. The prevention program consists of the following elements: 



? Employee Participation Program: 

The Plant has an overall safety program that includes employee awareness and training to minimize the potential for an accident or incident involving the ammonia refrigeration equipment.   

? Process Safety Information: 

Ammonia refrigeration equipment manuals and plant design technical specifications including piping diagrams are on file.  

? Process Hazard Analysis: 

A process hazard analysis (PHA) re-validation was conducted in June 2014 and another PHA re-validation is schedule for June 2019.   A team with expertise in engineering, operations, maintenance, and safety evaluated the existing refrigeration system in depth and developed recommendations to improve the safety and operability of the system.  The PHA addressed:  (1) process hazards; (2) previous incidents; (3) engineering and administrative controls applicable to the hazards; (4) the consequence of control failure; (5) facility siting; (6) human factors; and (7) a qualitative evaluation of possible safety and health effects

of control system failures.  

? Operating Procedures: 

Written Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) were prepared to provide the basis for proper and safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  The SOPs include procedures for normal operations, startup, shutdown, emergency operations, and emergency shutdown.  

? Training Program: 

An operator training program is designed to ensure that the systems are operated by qualified personnel.  

? Contractor Safety Program: 

Contractors that are used to work on or adjacent to the refrigeration system are "pre-qualified" based upon their knowledge of ammonia refrigeration, understanding of applicable codes and standards, and their demonstrated ability to work safely.  Each of these contractors is evaluated from a safety perspective.  

? Pre-Startup Safety Review Procedures: 

See comments under Management of Change  

? Mechanical Integrity Program: 

The Plant has a program for replacement of all Safety Relief Valves on a 5 year interval as recommended by IIAR.  We also have a preventive maintenance program designed to maintain the on-going integrity of the system.  

? Hot Work Permit Procedures: 

The plant has implemented a Hot Work permit program including training.  

? Management of Change Procedures: 

For projects, a management of change procedure and a pre-startup safety review are in place to ensure that system changes or expansions are safe and that the changes are consistent with the engineering design and in condition to be operated prior to startup.  

? Incident Investigation Procedures: 

An incident investigation program is in place at the plant to review incidents and implement any identified improvement(s) to reduce future potential for new incidents to occur.  

? Compliance Audit Procedures: 

At least every three years a full program audit is conducted.  



D. Five-Year Accident History 



There have been no accidents as defined by EPA Risk Management in the past 5 years that have resu

lted in a death, injury, or significant property damage on site or off-site death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.  

 

E. Description of the Emergency Response Program 



An emergency response program has been implemented at the facility. This program contains procedures describing how the facility will respond to ammonia spills and other emergencies, including evacuation procedures. The program has been coordinated with local fire department officials. 



The emergency response program is based upon federal guidelines as they apply to this facility.  The emergency response plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority, local emergency response agencies, and notification of any potentially affected neighbors. The facility emergency response plan is based on all known applicable regulations and requirements.  The emergency response plan has been discussed with the Algona Fire Department and other agencies involved with response.  Representatives of the Algona Fire Department visit this plant on an annual basis.  



The facility has a trained team of emergency responders that are available to respond to any ammonia release.  This trained staffs are skilled at responding to a release and isolating problem areas within the ammonia refrigeration system.  



F. Planned Changes to Improve Safety 



Identification of opportunities and changes to improve safety is part of the culture of this plant.  In addition to the plant programs mentioned above, the following changes are planned. 

Algona Food has demonstrated and plans several changes to improve employee

and environmental safety, including but not limited to:

      -     Machinery Room upgrades including ventilation to IIAR recommendations;

      -     Annual employee Emergency Response Training; and 

-    Assessing refrigeration needs and moving equipment to the roof.
